review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972085674', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 615, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 615, 'last_played': 1708374822}
review:
Looks like a typical bullet hell, but the introduction of puzzle game elements creates something radically different. Instead of a typical manic shooter, this is a game of patience and precision where you're constantly looking for the exact right moment to trigger an explosion. Being able to clear the entire screen feels super satisfying.

Beyond the basic gameplay, there's an excellent story, gradually revealed through cryptic fragments as you unlock achievements. There's a guide, but I honestly recommend going in as blind as possible - this is a game where it's more fun to figure out how everything works on your own. The hand-drawn character portraits and exceptional soundtrack both complement the story and gameplay perfectly, imbuing it with an atmosphere of beauty and tragedy.

You don't need to fear the typical demanding standards of bullet hell games here, you get a life bar and relatively drequent health pickups, so anyone should be able to clear the story without too much difficulty. The postgame extra stages and modes are more experts-only in terms of difficulty, but you can get an extremely satisfying experience just from beating the main game.

Honestly a godlike game.

author: {'steamid': '76561199043268001', 'num_games_owned': 171, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1700098889}
review:
Really fun STG that puts a refreshing spin on danmaku gameplay. The devs are obviously massive Touhou fans and like minded folks will likely appreciate it. The crux of the game is bouncing colored blocks into each other to set off chain explosions to destroy enemy bullets, with the catch being that you can only shoot one bullet at a time. Sounds simple but in practice it can be a fiendishly tricky task, like trying to line up a billiard shot through oncoming traffic. With a handful of stages and two characters to choose from, there's a lot of fun to be had in playing for score. Visual clarity is good, as attack patterns are easily identifiable. Mechanically, this game is solid, but I know some people will miss having a precise marker for the character's hitbox like in other shooters. Overall difficulty is fair provided you have an understanding of the mechanics.

For a quirky little shooter, this game also has a lot of soul. Character design is solid, and I love the banter between the player characters and the stage bosses. The game also strikes a good balance with just enough world building to get you invested in the scenario. I'm not ashamed to admit that the boss in stage 5 had me tearing up a bit.  The music also slaps unreasonably hard. Influences include jazz fusion, funk, lounge music, some bits of rock, baroque, and even a touch of modern classical. Not a single bad apple in the whole bunch, and always feels fitting to the situation. Whoever watson is, they were cooking real good on this project. There's also a lot of cool sequencing that the game does with the soundtrack and gameplay.

This game is criminally underrated, and the price is honestly a steal. While you might consider passing up Murasaki for it's sequel, I'd recommend picking up both, as the first game does a better job of introducing the mechanics for the first time, whereas the second builds upon it and is a bit more difficult. A solid recommend in my book.

review:
名作です。カタテマ作品はどれもシステムにオリジナリティがありつつも面白いのが特徴ですが、このゲームもそうです。出てくるパズルをうって移動させる、という部分には「いりす症候群」のシステムを感じますね。久しぶりに1から遊びなおしていますがやはり面白いです。
システム自体が面白いのは当然として、やりこむほど「コレクション」で明らかになるストーリーや世界観も非常に魅力的で、そこから何があったかのほとんどを理解した後のステージ5の演出は泣けます。もう泣くことはないのではないかと思っていましたが、あの曲を聞くと自然と涙が出てしまいます……。

ただやりこみの難易度は高いので、コレクションを全て埋められる日が来るのかがひたすら心配になります。

author: {'steamid': '76561198201246082', 'num_games_owned': 3232, 'num_reviews': 1499, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 299, 'last_played': 1653630901}
review:
Murasaki, Katatema tarafından geliştirilen ve PLAYISM tarafından yayınlanan bir bulmaca patlama oyunudur. Bir shoot 'em up unsurlarını bulmaca çözme oyunuyla birleştirir. Oyun, yıkımın eşiğindeki mistik bir dünyada geçmektedir ve oyuncular engelleri temizlemek için patlamaları kullanmalıdır. Oyunda, her biri kendine özgü yeteneklere ve özel saldırılara sahip iki oynanabilir karakter, Kairi ve Satsuki bulunmaktadır. Oyuncular hayatta kalmak ve oyunun seviyelerinde ilerlemek için kurnazlık, açılar ve zamanlama kullanmalıdır.

Oyunun mekaniği, ekranda beliren rastgele şekillere ateş etmeyi ve vurulduğunda büyük patlamaları tetiklemeyi içerir. Oyuncular, ekrandaki engelleri ortadan kaldıran zincirleme reaksiyonlar oluşturmak için atışlarını hedeflemeli ve zamanlamalıdır. Her karakterin ayrıca zor durumlardan kurtulmak veya patronları yenmek için kullanılabilecek sınırlı kullanımlı özel bir saldırısı vardır.

Oyunun hikayesi, seviyelerin başarıyla tamamlanması, yeni bilgilerin, geçmişin, biyografilerin ve müzik parçalarının kilidinin açılmasıyla kademeli olarak ortaya çıkar. Oyun ayrıca ekran boyutu, BGM/SE oranı ve tuş bağlamaları için bir yapılandırma aracı sunar.

Murasaki'nin oynanışı hızlı tempolu ve yoğundur, muhteşem müziklerle dingin ve güzel bir manzaraya karşı ayarlanmıştır. Oyuncular merkezlerini bulmalı ve oyunda ilerlemek için kaçma ve patlamadan oluşan akıcı bir ritme girmelidir. Oyunun mekaniklerinde ustalaşmak başarı için çok önemlidir, bu da tatmin edici ve ödüllendirici bir deneyim sağlar.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063035714', 'num_games_owned': 352, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 882, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 882, 'last_played': 1654361518}
review:
Normally i wait until i've 100%ed a game before dropping a review on it but...
...yeah i can't do it, that extra stage is absolutely fucking RIDICULOUS, ended up giving up on it because i could not even SCRAPE a win against the boss

Seriously though, this is the best ultra-cheap game that i can't fully beat, it's like a weird Touhou clone (and i'm not saying this as a negative, you can tell just by looking at the gameplay and the slightly-janky character art) with a completely different and interesting overall progression method, and you play things PER-STAGE as opposed to having to do full runs of the game in one go (which arguably makes it MORE comfortable to progress through, since it's less commitment than a full single-sitting game run).

The main catch with the "schmup" gameplay is that you don't JUST shoot enemies (well you can but it's unoptimal), as you can only fire a single bullet at a time and it's not particularly damaging.
Here's the thing; YOUR bullet goes through and erases ENEMY bullets (and bounces off the top of the screen to come back down).

What you ACTUALLY do is pay attention to the stage around you as colored blocks slowly spawn in (just don't touch them, they count as "enemy projectiles"), and then you shoot THESE blocks to turn them into physics props that will slide and bounce across the screen and activate OTHER blocks of the same color they touch; they'll fly in different angles depending on how you hit them rewarding careful aim, and the more blocks hit each other at once, the bigger and more damaging the explosion the blocks will release after a few seconds, and the more absolutely DEVASTATING it is (including clearing even more enemy bullets with those explosions).

The actual spawns of these blocks seem to be entirely RNG-based, but they spawn often enough that assuming you don't waste them the second you see them you'll have PLENTY of stuff to work with soon enough, and with how polished the physics on these are it makes playing around with those and racking up chains REALLY stupidly fun.

The actual game progression (aside from just clearing all the stages one by one) centers around the MISSIONS in the game; a gigantic wall of tiles, each corresponding to one specific mission or objective for you to complete while playing, and completing each mission awards you with either a sound test song or a piece of trivia/story on the game's world, as well as revealing the information/unlock requirements for adjacent missions.
...It's essentially an Air Ride/Smash Bros deal, if you've played either of those games.

The story is kind of all over the place (and a lot of things are purposefully left ambiguous or up to interpretation), but it DOES make progression more fun, getting to unlock extra tidbits of info with each mission you complete and slowly piecing together what's supposed to be going on.

The biggest draw though... The MUSIC.
The music in this game is GENUINELY, ABSOLUTELY one of my favorites i've heard in any obscure small indie game like this, it's RIDICULOUS how good and how varied it is, ranging from cool-ass jazzy/funky tunes to straight up techno/house beats, and ALL of them are catchy as hell [strike]save for the blander guitar/rock tunes that i don't like all that much[/strike].
Really though, just HAVING the music in the background makes playing this game a lot more fun somehow.


[b]TLDR:[/b] It's cheap as shit, it's got cool mechanics and the music is GODLY, [i]absolutely[/i] get it especially if you see it on sale

review:
Really nice but different than usual bullet hell game where the story is told through achievements. The gameplay seems confusing at first but becomes really fun once you figure it out. (If you're struggling to understand the mechanics, you can check the manual in your library. It explains stuff in more detail.)

What makes this game really amazing, is in my opinion, the soundtrack. I came with high expectations after playing Irisu Syndrome, another game by the same developer, which Watson also composed for and I was definitely not disappointed. Watson has done an incredible job composing for this game. While the game itself is really good and I loved the puzzle-like aspect of it, the music is what ultimately made me fall in love with the game.

Definitely worth the money! I'm really looking forward to playing the sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561199218208026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1705777955}
review:
Mursaki is one of those games that look confusing, but is actually really simple. I got this game for a dollar because it was on sale and it was recommended a lot, so I gave it a try. I ended up falling in love with the simple match 3 gameplay that happens in a bullet hell playing field. I haven't beaten all of the stages because replaying stages to get a higher score is addicting. The second stage may throw you off because you will die almost instantly. Maneuver a little and then the stage opens up. I'll set a pros / cons for my early experience.

Pros:
Fun & Addicting Gameplay Loop
Music is really good and works well with said gameplay
Two ways to play (Fast and short shot and Long shot) for variety

Cons: 
I think the aspect ratio windowed mode it keeps you in is fine. It's like any RPG Maker game. It's just a little small
The art can be hit or miss, but the pixel art is really what you'll see, which is clear and looks good

Overall, I love playing this game. It was cheap and runs on any computer. I like clearing an entire screen of projectiles. It's very satisfying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122886037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1574508627}
review:
这是一个难以归类到任何游戏类型的游戏。这种设计方法偶尔会出现别出心裁的优秀作，但大部分时候都是新手游戏设计者想当然设计出来的平庸作品。
Murasaki是一个东方风格的游戏，它继承了东方极其优秀的音乐水平。
基本上我买这款游戏以及把这款游戏玩下去的动力就是它的音乐，这种水平的音乐完全可以在大部分音乐游戏中占据相当高的地位。
而游戏体验本身却很尴尬，太随意想当然。它的主要消弹和攻击方式是弹射砖块，但因为砖块是地图上随机刷新的，就难以让玩家有着“靠自己的努力击败敌人”的正向反馈。而且增加输出的方式难以像诸如宝石迷阵那样通过玩家的策略规划来实现，只要等待足够长的时间就能打出很高的连锁。这种策略难以产生更多的深度。
最后一关甚至还出现了音乐突然消失，部分音效消失的bug。但多少也算无巧不成书吧，最后那部分的战斗里，在一片嘈杂之中突然万籁俱静，钢琴曲奏响，将玩家带入一种寂寞伤感的氛围当中，可以想象如果处理得当会是相当惊艳的氛围塑造。
希望作者能够在未来做出更多更好的作品吧。

author: {'steamid': '76561198859098173', 'num_games_owned': 10308, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 296, 'last_played': 1572583268}
review:
Murasaki is an obscure, simple but clever game by the Doujin Circle, Katatema, that combines the aesthetic sensibilities of Touhou with the cerebral storytelling and some gameplay similarities of Irisu Syndrome (which should come as no surprise as they developed that game too). Utilizing two primary buttons and the arrow keys, the player flys around as either the male Kairi or female Satsuki shooting projectiles at enemies/bullets while grabbing basic power-ups (health upgrades, bomb stock) and making it to the boss at the end of a level. However, the game takes a cue from Irisu Syndrome by throwing in mild physics and an integral puzzle element by placing different colored bombs on the field. They pop up at regular intervals and when hit, bounce around the screen, ricocheting into same-colored bombs. The more bombs that touch before they detonate, the more powerful the explosion. The player's own bomb works similarly as it can be charged by holding down the button, but should only be used in emergencies.

While the concept is easy to learn, it is hard to master as some strategy is involved as far as where and when to set off bombs all while evading enemy fire, but the game does a good job of easing you into the hell of bullets (except that segment at the start of level two...that's just odd). This would make for a fun diversion in and of itself, but they also threw in challenges to unlock content and "duels" that are triggered by different conditions and change the dialogs of your adversaries, should you choose to let them say their piece or attack them while they talk instead. 

Playing as each character yields different results as, unlike most shooters, you have a very slow rate of fire. Kairi has a long range but a very slow rate of fire while Satsuki has a very short range but a faster rate of fire. The scenery and beautiful music by Watson helps fill in some of the gaps left by the game's limited text and delivers an emotional experience.

IMO: 7.5 / 10 PTS

author: {'steamid': '76561198242787922', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 937, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 526, 'last_played': 1654269476}
review:
「魔王物語物語」「愛と勇気とかしわもち」のカタテマさん制作のゲームということでセール時に購入しました。カタテマさんの作品にお金が払えるなんて最高ですね…　魔王物語物語もsteamで出てほしいですね。
12時間プレイで実績を3分2ほど解除しました。


〇ゲーム
東方プロジェクトのようなSTGに見えますが、自機の弾幕で敵を倒していくのではなく、画面に現れるブロックをビリヤードのようにはじき連鎖爆発してブロック、敵を倒していくゲームです。カタテマさんのゲームはシステムが独特のものが多く期待していましたがムラサキも大当たりでした。必死に弾幕をよけてから一気に消していくのは快感です。弾幕をよける難易度は東方でノーマルクリアできる方なら余裕だと思います。ステージごとのボス戦も先への進め方がストーリーとリンクしていて、ただ敵を倒せばいいというわけではなく試行錯誤して進めていく楽しさがあります。特に二面と五面は十回やってやっと気が付きました…

〇音楽
すべていいです。もともとフリーゲームですが音楽を買うためにゲームとセット購入しました。ジャケットのデザインはpngで同梱されています。iTunesでも購入できますが750円とsteamより高いです。サントラの音楽形式はwav,mp3,flacの三種類ずつ入っていました。ゲーム内でカットされているところも入っているため、最後まで聴いてみたい方はぜひセットで買ってください。
個人的には「遠来は迷い子を告げる」が好きです。この曲を聴くために実績解除後も三面で遊んでいました。

〇ストーリー
はじめはなぜ主人公達が戦っているのか、主人公の目的も分からなかったのですが、実績を解除するごとに世界観が明かされていきます。キャラも皆濃い！ラストはもう…STGで号泣したのは初めてです。ネタバレなしで自分でやってほしいです。
主人公二人によってボスとの会話も変わっています。


カタテマさんの他のゲームにも言えることですが説明がなく自分で世界観を明らかにしていく、その過程で何度やっても飽きないゲームシステムの良さ、音楽とシステムの調和、すべてが気持ちよく作られています。
無料でも遊べますがカタテマさんを支援したい、素晴らしい音楽をゆっくり聴きたい方にはぜひおすすめします。

review:
Un juego muy infravalorado que tiene un sistema jugable muy interesante, más parecido a shooters atipicos como Gigawing o Touhou Shoot the Bullet. El creador de Irisu Syndrome nos trae un juego que consiste en usar reacciones en cadena de bombas que van apareciendo por la pantalla para eliminar enemigos o devolverles sus proyectiles. Unido a ello tenemos un sistema de puntuación y dificultad dinámica (como poder prolongar batallas contra jefes haciendo que entren en sus fases más peligrosas de forma opcional a cambio de obtener más puntos o un par de combates extra por jugar de forma pacifista). 
Además, las situaciones que nos ofrece el juego hacen que la jugabilidad se expanda maravillosamente. 

Mi única queja es que la aparición y posicionamiento de bombas es muy dependiente del azar, por lo que siempre tendrá ese pequeño factor de influencia en la batalla.

review:
Dos criadores do puzzle de horror Irisu Syndrome! (いりす症候群!). Um shmup simples, extremamente único e cheio de segredos, que empresta mecânicas de Irisu.

O foco do jogo não está em desviar de tiros, mas em usar seus tiros estrategicamente para atingir blocos, gerando uma reação em cadeia que cancela tiros e mata inimigos. É muito comum você derrotar um chefe sem atirar nele sequer uma vez, o que faz com que esse jogo seja jogado de uma forma bem diferente de qualquer outro shmup.

A história do jogo, além de melancólica, possui um forte clima de mistério - os diálogos de chefes te dão pouca informação e não fazem muito sentido. Mas realizando conquistas (achievements) você libera explicações sobre perfil de personagens, história, etc. Com isso você vai juntando as peças e entendendo o que está acontecendo - a história é, de certa forma, um quebra-cabeças que deve ser resolvido. É um shmup que exige "exploração".

A trilha sonora é ótima, os gráficos são simples, de baixa resolução, mas muito elegantes. As artes do jogo também tem um estilo bem definido imitando rascunhos inacabados, complementando o clima de mistério do jogo.

Esse clima está não só na história e na arte, mas também nas mecânicas. Existem [i]muitas[/i] coisas secretas para serem descobertas, e em pouco tempo dá pra perceber que simplesmente atirar sem pensar não vai te levar muito longe.

A dificuldade do jogo é razoável, com uma curva bem adequada (com algumas pequenas exceções intencionais). Há também um modo difícil e um estágio extra para os que quiserem um desafio extra. Não existe algo como um "arcade mode", os estágios são sempre feitos individualmente. Ao invés de repetir estágios múltiplas vezes para terminar o jogo sem "continues", você tentará terminar eles de formas diferentes para encontrar os segredos.

É um jogo simples, curto mas feito com bastante amor e bastante único, mas que irá esconder as coisas de você e exigir que você as procure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072142271', 'num_games_owned': 252, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1618, 'last_played': 1506419784}
review:
If you happen to have played Irisu Syndrome by the same developer, this one can be described as Irisu meets Touhou, without any scary surprises.

Otherwise, to explain it simply, it's a vertical bullet hell shooting game with an empashis on bullet canceling. You can shoot only one bullet at a time, and while it does clear enemy fire as well as damage them, relying only on that is going to get you killed fast. Instead, you can shoot the colored shapes that appear throughout the level at a steady pace and try to make them bounce against each other: the block will soon explode and destroy anything in its area of effect. Each time the block you shot bumps into another one of the same shape and color, it will cause the second one to explode too, as well as increasing the power and radius of the blast.
That means that rather than squeezing through minuscule openings, you're encouraged to make use of the puzzle-like system to find the perfect moment and angle to hit the blocks and stop the bullets before they even reach you at all. This easy to understand core mechanic remains unchanged for the whole game, but never gets boring as you start to master it and find new ways to save yourself from a difficult spot. The two characters play similarly, with their normal shot being the biggest change: Kairi shoots a bullet that travels to the end of the screen and back, while Satsuki has a short range shot with much higer knockback and creates bigger explosions.

Another important difference from other shmups is that this one doesn't have extra lives or power-ups. Instead, you have a health bar, that can be occasionally replenished by picking up health items, and there is [b] no mercy invincibility[/b] at all, so you can't just let yourself hit it to pass a pattern. You do however have the traditional smart bombs for emergency situations.

Bosses work like Touhou, with the added bonus that some of their attacks are optional and come in the forms of "duels": if you play well enough, the boss coughs up a little red blob, and picking it up initiates an additional pattern. These create 
great opportunities for high-scorers, while beginners can easily ignore them with no repercussion.

The game has 5 main stages, which do get progressively more challenging but are easier than what you'd find in most "pure" STGs, and an extra 6th stage which ramps the difficulty up to eleven. If you're going for completion, be ready to have your patience tested. There is also a survival mode where you can try to endure the enemy assault for as long as you can, and a absurdly difficult "hard mode", that is thankfull not required for anything.
Beating the game should take from 2 to 6 hours depending on your skill level and dedication, while clearing it 100% will extend the longevity quite a bit (took me more than 20 hours to manage everything, just to give you an idea, although to be fair I'm not a master player).

Interestingly, despite being a shoot-em-up, a visible amount of care went into the backstory, which you can unlock little by little by collecting the achievements. It's not the main focus of the game, but it's nice to have a sembiance of plot that is not just a complete excuse to shoot things down, and it's a nice rewards for those willing to go the extra mile.

As for the technical side: enemy mobs are pretty much all variations of the same design, sadly, but the character and bosses' portraits are much more detailed and good-looking. The soundtrack is also easy on the ears and goes perfectly with the flow of the game, especially during the later levels.
I didn't encounter any notable bug, and can confirm PS3 and PS4 controllers both work fine.

[b]Summary[/b]:
+ Unique gameplay concept
+ Interesting lore and backstory
+ Good OST
+/-  Challenging.
-  Slightly lazy mobs design and behaviour. Visual effects could also be a bit better.
-  Relatively short if you don't care about completion.
A breath of fresh air in the genre, and a completely unique shoot 'em up that any fan of the genre should be able to enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198159557537', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 435, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 372, 'last_played': 1534724700}
review:
Unexpectedly good and ridiculously underrated, but not without flaws.

This is a game about clearing bullets off of the screen - this shouldn't be compared to Touhou or any of Cave's shmups, simply because you have a lot more control over the bullet density. The mechanic for clearing bullets off of the screen is simple - you shoot one of the colored blocks and it explodes, clearing bullets. If the colored block hits a similarly colored block, then the explosion is larger, in proportion to how many blocks you hit.

Usually, there's two different colors. The fact that you can choose which colored block to hit opens up a lot of very good mixed strategies for the veteran, which makes the game mechanic significantly more fun than it would be with just one color. There's harder stages with three colors, which has the effect of making things easier if you are very good, and harder if you are not.

The artistic style is incredibly good. First, the bullet patterns are fresh. Most bullet patterns in most games have the effect of pushing the cautious player down, but the cautious player in this game will sometimes feel himself pushed upwards, which is interesting. You really feel like you're using the entire screen to play very often, which is really good. Second, the art itself, though unpolished a little, is quite beautiful. Last, however, the music is absurdly good - "bringing you to tears and making you serously consider buying the OST" good. Perhaps the first thing I thought with respect to the style was that this is the game most US indie gamers wish they could make - a game that is undeniably a piece of art, but without any of the pretentiousness that typically burdens such games.

I must admit that I take issue with three things: first, the second stage is notably harder than most of the rest of the game. This feels incredibly unbalanced. For someone who is good, this will not matter much, but it is not a good thing. I can imagine this being a significant hurdle for someone new. I would have put that particular opening sequence in a later stage, but the burstiness of it definitely fits the character of the second boss.

Second (spoiler), there does not appear to be indication in-game that you should not destroy the last stage midbosses in order to get the good ending. This is very counterintutive.

Third, there is not a middle difficulty. The unprotected mode feels like "Hard" or "Extra Hard" mode, while the protected mode feels like "Easy" mode.

The third flaw makes me hesitant to categorically recommend this game - I thus conditionally recommend it. If you're starting out and trying to branch out, the protected mode of this game is a good way to do this. If you're mildly skilled (using Touhou as a yardstick, 1cc'ing most Touhou games on normal being no challenge, but 1cc'ing most Touhou games on hard being a bit beyond you) and you want a sort of challenge, the unprotected mode of this game is definitely a way to go. If you're very skilled, then perhaps spending 8 or so hours admiring the art and bullet patterns is worthwhile.

The only group of people I must say who should avoid this game are people who have a low, but not very low, level of skill. Unprotected mode will be too hard, and protected mode will be too easy.

Get good, then blow $5 on this game. The experience will be very worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107973832', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1490220449}
review:
Ingenious game that combines a shooting game with puzzle elements. At first it may seem the puzzle element overshadows the shooting game but that's only when the game is teaching you the mechanics in the beginning. Later on it gets demanding and expects you to master both strategic shooting and bullet dodging.

The main mechanic of the game is sort of a block puzzle. By shooting colored blocks on the backround layer you can push them around. Knock blocks of the same colour into eachother and they explode dealing damage to enemies and bullets. Larger chains deal more damage. If you cancel bullets this way on bosses they take damage. This may sound confusing but the game really shows you through it and in the end the core mechanic is quite simple. The challenge to the player is figuring out how to deal with various situations on the fly. Often times you'll find yourself thinking out when to shoot and figure out a plan while managing your way through bullet curtains. Murasaki encourages you to be smart about your shooting sort of like Ikaruga or old school 80's shmups.

A bullet health system is the other half of the puzzle mechanic. A bullets color matches its health and they are damaged by block explosions or the players shot. It's implemented quite well and makes you choose between shots or the size of block chains to go for. The default character is far better at cancelling bullets (ie. defense) while the other can land bigger attacks off the puzzle blocks. The latter also has to be careful going to the top of its screen as she has little range to shoot downwards. However dont expect to be able to always rely on bullet cancels, on higher health patterns this wont work. Often to get larger block chains for tricky sections you will end up not shooting for extended periods and having to dodge much more.

Murasaki's soundtrack is really amazing, top notch and there's a lot of competition in this genre. The chill music on stages goes well with the puzzle element and boss themes match their intensity. A fair bit of music syncing, especially with the true route of stage 5. Even if you're not a fan of the gameplay itself the music might surprise you.

After getting the ending you unlock the 6th extra stage which is far more challenging than anything preceding it. The boss of this stage truly demands some dodging skills and figuring out the tricks of its patterns. If you're not a shmup veteran this stage will likely be a wall, but smart play is still always rewarded so it can be enjoyable to learn shmups in this way.

The game includes a hard mode for the first 5 stages which makes their difficulty curve match more with the extra stage. The bosses get significantly harder and you need to approach some stage sections more as a puzzle. Stage 6 on normal is still tougher than anything in hard mode. There's also an endless stage that really tests your skill in the puzzle element as you cannot memorize and it keeps on getting tougher.

Definitely one of the best value for money for STG/shmups on Steam unless you have an aversion to bullet cancelling gimmicks. Murasaki implements its idea well and is a joy to play. Should be refreshing to anyone who thinks shmups are out of innovative ideas. It's worth noting this was first released as a free game, and for that it is quite amazing.

review:
(パブリッシャーが運営する販売サイトで購入してのレビュー)

ゲーム画面を見て既存のタイトルを連想される方もいるだろうが、この作品をプレイして得られる体験は独特のものになるはずである。

[list]
[*]画面上に次々と現れるブロックに自機の弾を撃ち、その勢いでブロック同士を連鎖させて大爆発を起こし敵や弾幕を一気に消していく弾幕＋アクションパズルのユニークなプレイ感
[*]当作ディレクターの過去作品である『勇者御一行様殺人事件』『魔王物語物語』『いりす症候群！』にも通じる巧妙なストーリーテリング(今作でどのような仕掛けになっているかはあえては言及しない)
[*]『いりす症候群！』でもBGMを担当した作曲家のwatson氏による、キャッチーなBGMの数々(余談ではあるが、私はこの作品のBGMを1年以上に渡ってほぼ毎日、ゲーム体験の感動を思い出しながら聴き続けている)
[/list]

これらが高いレベルでまとまっているものはとても貴重であると思った。

ただ、細かいながらも気になる点がある事には公正を期す為にも言及しておく。

[list]
[*]会話シーンやメニュー画面におけるテキストのフォントレンダリングがあまりよろしくない。全体的な雰囲気が良いだけに残念なところである
[*]英語版において、会話シーンでのテキスト表示時間がテキストの長さと合っていない。また、曲名表示で長いものについては省略表記になってしまっているといった、おそらくは開発当初にローカライズを考慮していなかったことによる仕様
[/list]

これらの点については(Steamでリリースされるかは不明であるが)予定されている続編では改善されていることを期待したい。

なお、当作品にはディレクター自身によってホームページなどで公開されている無料版が存在している(Steam版との違いはクラウドセーブ・実績といったSteam向けの機能が無い、日本語版のみであるというところ)。
この作品のコアな部分を体験するのであれば無料版でも十分ではあるものの、ファンとしては是非とも制作者やパブリッシャーを支援する為にもこの有料版の購入を検討していただきたい。

author: {'steamid': '76561198049747450', 'num_games_owned': 904, 'num_reviews': 162, 'playtime_forever': 3339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3126, 'last_played': 1498670388}
review:
商売の邪魔をするつもりではないんですが
＊日本語版はフリーソフトなんで必ず買う必要はないです。＊

でもってこのゲーム、すごいんです。ちゃんと説明します。

まず、下敷きは当然「東方」シリーズです。じゃあオリジナリティないの？ってオリジナリティしかないんです。
ショット威力はほとんどありません。ほぼすべての敵弾は潰すことができ、その相殺はショットでも行えるのですが
二面からはもう固い敵弾ばかりで全然通らなくなります。

じゃあどうするのか？
なんか湧いてくる図形を打て！
図形は反射し、図形同士で連鎖し、連鎖数に応じた爆発をします。その爆風で弾消しを行うのです。

このシステムが愉快なところはいくつもあります。
・図形を画面に溜めて特徴的な弾が大きくばらまかれる地点に投げ込むことで簡単に高得点ができます。
・図形は時間経過でしか沸かないので、同時消し＝大爆発させることで画面クリア級の爆風になりますが
　それは逆に図形がなくなり防御面でおろそかになります。
まずこの２つが相反していますよね。
沢山弾を溜めて消すゲームはありましたが、弾消しの回数を絞ったり、ゲージにしたり、特定のリスクを背負わせるところにはデザイナーが頭を悩ませるところでしたが、このゲームは一手でそれを解決しています。

また
・図形自体がプレイヤーにもダメージ判定あるので沸き待ち自体にリスクがあり高得点狙いへの難易度の係数をうまくひきあげています。

ストーリーは全くわからない状態から始まりますが徐々に全貌が見えてきます。
この万華鏡風の絵柄同様、物語もくるくると見え方を変え、最終的に行き着いたところでストーリーも氷解するようになっています。
このあたりは作者お得意の叙述形式でしょうか。
とても残酷な世界ですが、STGが自機のみを拠り所に突き進む形式であることを考えると当然の帰結でもあるかと思います。

またなにより音楽の素晴らしさ！
ネタバレになる部分ですが、ラストの音楽はストーリーを知って聞くととっても感動しますよ。
そうなんです。
ストーリーと音楽が噛み合っていて、なおかつ音楽に合わせて弾が出るのでゲームシステムともがっちり噛み合っているのです。
こんなこと、普通できませんよ。出来て一部です。ラスボス戦だけ感動の！みたいな。
そうじゃなくて、全編それなんです。
音楽がゲームステージになり、ゲームの理解が音楽の理解になるんです。

言っちゃ悪いですけど、IGNとかこれちゃんと評価できていないなら価値ないですよ。
メタスコア？90あるでしょ。
オリジナリティ100、リプレイ性100、面白さ100、可愛さ100、音楽100、難しさは万人受けは難しいから75。
こんなもんだろ報道各社様よー。まさかわからないってことはないよね？
それとも出せないんですか。
怖いんですか。才能が。

そんなわけで皆様にあたってはサムズアップでお願いします。

review:
Murasaki is an obscure shmup that lets you shoot to activate shapes using either of the two characters available. Have the activated shapes touch others of the same shape to cause an explosion, damaging enemies and erasing bullets in the blast. (This mechanic is identical to the one in [i]Irisu Syndrome[/i] because it is made by the same person.)

In addition, there is a deep story that you can uncover as you clear stages and fulfill achievement conditions. Beating all the stages is no easy task. Good luck.

Also the dialogue seems weirdly bugged (can't tell who's speaking at the right times in some parts), but this is not much of an issue as they're mostly short.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046193538', 'num_games_owned': 701, 'num_reviews': 248, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1492909729}
review:
This game is very unique. If I had to give an analagous comparison, I'd say it'd be the lovechild between a single-player Phantasmagoria of Flower View and Air Hockey. If that made absolutely no sense, then continue reading.

This game has several stages you can choose from, and only one fixed difficulty. Completing a stage unlocks the next stage, and you can play any stage at will. The first stage is a low-key tutorial with passive messages explaining the game's mechanics, but it's not a tutorial stage; it's the first stage. The controls are very simple; use the directional keys to move, one button to shoot, and another button to charge up your 'bomb' which clears many bullets around you. These controls, as well as the game's resolution (options limited to 160x120, 320x240, 640x480, 800x600, and 1280x960) and fullscreen/windowed settings can be changed in the config menu option upon startup, but cannot be changed in-game.

Gameplay consists of maneuvering your character through whatever bullets may be present and firing your one shot straight forward. Yes, one; you can only have one shot on screen at a time, but it's not nearly as bad as it sounds. Your shot removes whatever bullets it hits along its path and disappears once it rebounds off the other side and goes through the bottom of the screen. The objective is to shoot the frequently spawning red and blue shapes which, when shot, will move in the direction you shot them and explode after a short time, doing damage to enemies and clearing bullets in a set radius. If you shoot a shape into another shape of the same color, it will cause a chain explosion, clearing even more bullets and doing more damage. Because your standard shot does very little damage on its own, boss battles are a constant battle of positioning, spacing, and carefully shooting the shapes into clusters of bullets, clearing them off the screen and subsequently damaging the boss.

In conclusion, this game's alright. It's very unique and feels weird at first, but doesn't take too long to get used to. Because your character has a health bar (that can be replenished if you do a super awesome chain reaction explosion), if you get hit with several bullets, it's not an instant game-over unlike several other danmaku games I've played. In that sense, it's rather forgiving, but in no way does that make it easy; as early as stage 2, the game expects you to have a firm understanding of the game's mechanics. I would definitely recommend this game if you want a new and unique take on the shoot-em-up genre, especially if it goes on sale.

[spoiler]I [i]really[/i] like the art style and how fuzzy the character's clothes look, but that has nothing to do with gameplay.[/spoiler]

review:
With such simple mechanics there is so much depth.  The bombs are both aids and obstacle.  Playing at the bottom or the top.  Clear the field or save for the midboss.  You are at the same time dodging bullets, avoiding obstacles, streaming enemies and planning how to clear the field. There is so much choice to make that are actually meaningful and yet only split second to decide.  

It is slow paced compared even to touhou, but it never feels slow.  The wall of bullets is a distant tsunami slowly approaching, but you know it will quickly wash you away.  So to protect your home you desperately try to break the wall of water with only a bucket.  That is what the final stage feels like.

What an amazing game.

review:
Murasaki:
~~~~~~~
 
How are your reflexes, people? Are they slow, medium or super-fast? The good news for you is, this game will make your reflexes top notch! Are you ready for a fun, fast and challenging bullet hell game? I bet you are. . .  Here it is, welcome to Murasaki!

At the start of the game, you will only be able to play the first of six available stages (the last stage needs to be unlocked). After choosing either Kairi (I recommend this character if you are a novice in this type of game) or Sutsaki, you will start the first level. This stage comes with a small tutorial and will show you what to do with the orange block and blue circles. Remember one important point – only one shot at a time!! There is no rapid fire in this game!  Hit either the orange blocks or the blue circles – they will explode within a few seconds!! Hit them in a certain way so they can travel to the most concentrated area of bullets and clear the zone!

How do the bullets appear? Well, you have several enemies. The most common ones are these funny white thingies with flowers on their heads! They spit bullets in all directions - even in a spiral! You will also have fish flying around and they will leave a trail of bullets, too. In the middle of the stage, you will have something like a mini boss to eliminate and then the last boss of the stage. 

The bullets come in different colours; you will have to hit the white ones only once, two shots for the blue and three shots for the yellow. However, you can create a chain reaction if you manage to put an orange block or a blue circle right in the middle of the biggest concentration of bullets. 

Pick up blue and red orbs, too. The blue ones will give you back some well-needed health while the red ones will give you access to an additional magic bomb. What is a magic bomb, you may ask? Well, if you are surrounded by a large number of bullets and can’t see how to get out of this peculiar situation, just activate the magic bomb and no more bullets around you - Yeehah!

Nice artworks. The soundtrack is sublime and you can choose either the keyboard or the gamepad for the controls. 

Positives:
~~~~~~~~  

-	Fast, fun and addictive game
-	Use blocks or circles to create chain reaction
-	Splendid soundtrack
-	Achievements and trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~  

-	I would like to see more stages

This is a hell of a game! I just thoroughly enjoyed it!

9/10

review:
和製フリーゲームのSteam移植版。もちろん日本語あり。
「魔王物語物語」「愛と勇気とかしわもち」「いりす症候群！」といった、
数多くの名作ゲームを手がけてきたサークル、カタテマによる作品。

一見すると弾幕シューティングに見えるが、
ブロックを撃って同じ色のブロックにぶつけることで爆発し、敵や弾幕を消すことが出来る。
ボス戦においては、爆発に巻き込んだ敵弾が敵に向かって飛んで行きダメージを与えることも出来る。
（自分の弾自体ではほとんどダメージを与えられない）
要するに、パズル要素が非常に強いゲーム。

とは言いつつも実際はある程度の弾幕回避は必要なわけで、難易度は総じて高め。
4面辺りから一気に難易度が跳ね上がる。
しかし大量連鎖を決めて弾幕を一掃した時の爽快感はたまらない。

そして何より、このゲームは雰囲気が非常に素晴らしい。
このゲームのために書き下ろされたBGMも名曲揃い。真ラスボス戦の曲は涙腺崩壊必至。

文句なしにオススメできるゲームですが、フリー版との違いがない（多分）ので、
実績やトレカに興味がなければフリー版をやれば十分かもしれません。
お金を払う価値は十分すぎるほどにあると思いますが。（そもそもフリーでこのクオリティなのがおかしい）
他の作品もSteamで出してくれたら、私は全部買います！

author: {'steamid': '76561198028030548', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1193, 'last_played': 1463784506}
review:
Before starting I should mention that I have had more time with this game than my total playtime would indicate as I have played the Japanese version prior to the Steam release.

The game is described as a hybrid shmup/puzzle game- but, I personally feel that it becomes something entirely unique by combining elements of the two. While some skills from other shmups will carry over to this game- if you try to play it too much like a classic shmup then it's easy to quickly be consumed by the onslaught of enemy projectiles. 

Rather than firing a constant stream of bullets the player only has a single bullet that can be fired once at a time. This bullet can clear weaker enemy bullets from the screen- but it's mainly used to hit blocks that spawn around the level. By knocking these blocks into each other the player is able to create explosions which can clear the area of bullets and destroy enemies. This means that rather than confront enemies directly the player must use the bullet to set up explosive combos and clear a path before they become overwhelmed.The game is designed in such a way that it's able to retain the high intensity and do-or-die nature of a shmup while also including the intricacy and deliberation of a puzzle game.

Much like the developer, Tetsu’s, other games- this game also features a few secrets and a clever way of presenting the narrative through the design of the game. Combine this with Watson’s amazing music and you end up with an intriguing somber atmosphere that’s difficult to find elsewhere.

If you’re looking for a fresh take on a classic genre then I would highly recommend checking this game out!

author: {'steamid': '76561198043820439', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 5245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1654638828}
review:
Murasaki does a good job of introducing higher difficulties for its original mechanics; you're not going to play bullet hell game the same way again(And luckily for me, I don't play other bullet hell games that much since Touhou 9). 

Been playing since first day release in its original Japanese version, and I still haven't beat 6th stage. it is increasingly difficult like every stage is more than twice the difficulty of the previous, but it is learnable with low-moderate frustration when you're new. The tolerance between complete failure and perfection gets tighter, but this is where its 'puzzler' element comes in and rewards perfection and better play satisfyingly, something I don't really feel it could ever come up from a Bullet-Hell game(usually normal enemies would come out, spit you patterns to dodge while hitting them and enemy patterns would just be forgotten, but not this one). 

The minimalistic(when compared to other Bullet-hell) concept is what it is and you have to overcome them as its featured mechanics(Otherwise it might not be your cup of tea)

Got the OST in CD and its always a treat for me to listen to T_Watson/MusMus(The soundtrack creator) works, A mix of genres here and there keeping the experience fresh(Yeah I still have to pay for the dlc to show that I own it don't I?)

Price point? I tend to support and ready to be a fan of what I'm paying for, otherwise I'm not buying; I'm not sure anyone need to buy then complain a perfectly working game that is fun to play.(Someone had already 100% Murasaki with hard mode on all stages, so its not 'untested' incompletable game). If I had it for free before and have to pay for localized version, given the chance to support the dev for making original concepts that works, why not? (Or maybe its because I've spent so much effort in the fanbase basically $5 means nothing)

Thanks for listening to my wish that this game has made its way into Steam! that was unexpected, but I've been using steamoverlay for Murasaki long before this game is even announced for localization, for screenshotting my way trying to read the Japanese version. :D

review:
Murasaki finally gets an English release on Steam. The original game was in Japanese. I originally played the Japanese version (without understanding a single word) and later on I saw it would get a release on Steam with English version. I'm a fan of Wtetsu's work, so I bought, even if I had played the Japanese version previously.

This is a bullethell game with some puzzle mechanics (borrowed from his other game, "Irisu Syndrome!, which is free-ware by the way"). You can shoot directly through the enemies (only one shot on screen, but they don't take long to vanish), or make chains with the red squares and blue circles. You can also use bombs in case you have too much stuff on screen. On bosses, sometimes a "kano" (red thingy) drops it and you can catch it. If you manage to beat it, you'll receive a brief part of the story on the Collection, along the time it took for you to defeat that part of the boss. 

The idea of shooting on other objects that aren't necessarily the boss works pretty well. Dodging the boss bullet's and doing something else while doing so.

You have two characters in your disposal on the beginning (I don't know if you can unlock more later, I haven't beat it completely yet, but by seeing the store page, I don't think so). Each one has their own abilities. Kairi which is a more balanced character and Satsuki which has more power, but more difficult to use. Each character has different dialogues as well (on bosses), and you need to play as each to unlock certain information about the story (unlocked on the collection).

Speaking of collection, you can unlock various goodies (like music, character information, and such) while you progress in-game.

I just feel a little pricey for a simple game like this. Another problem is there is no way to "slow down" your character to dodge the bullets more easily, especially how the character moves kinda fast in this game. May be a good or bad thing, depending of your skill level.

Small bug: For some reason, the game seems to disable the Windows key (Running on Windows 7, 64-bits).

Pros:
- Good soundtrack;
- Interesting gameplay;
- Multiple routes (two characters to play as with different dialogue, and both of them unlocks specific features on the collection and your main story);
- Portrait artwork is pretty good.

Middle:
- Sprites and effects are ok.

Cons:
- No button for slow down the character (may not be a con, actually);
- Kinda pricey right now.
(Note: Game purchased on Brazil. The price on your location can be cheaper or more expensive).

(I may update this review when I beat it or something).

review:
steam版还没开始仔细玩就评价实在是不好意思。不过玩过原作的话推荐肯定是推荐的。
看上去像弹幕射击类（STG）游戏。。事实上是有很大解密成分的动作类游戏，趣味十足，难度也是有的。
boss战分为“普通身”和“狂暴身”（好吧，名字是自己起的），“狂暴身”都是有名字的，这点相当类似于东方非符符卡的模式，
顺便说一句原作是一款免费游戏，steam版貌似只是翻译英文以及增加了点steam相应的功能，如果不愿意花钱的话，访问官网就可以免费下载游戏（当然好像只有日文版）。
当然如果买了steam的游戏，ost是绝对要买的，这作的ost真的是绝赞，说36（不打折是42）元买一个ost送游戏我都觉得是超值的。

玩了一段时间，感觉可以写写后记了。
本来只是想说有一点难度，但实际深入玩起来难度比自己想的还要大的多，大概是没玩过类似游戏的原因。[spoiler] （当然，不得不说真的很好玩）	[/spoiler]
看上去只有五关，但是隐藏要素非常多，较高难度也能让人投入很多的时间来玩它。[spoiler]（终于过了5面，结果至今卡6boss233）。	[/spoiler]

下面说一下感觉不足的地方
1.没有低速，对于我这种弹幕游戏玩的多，总会去强迫去按shift的逗比来说简直是噩梦。而且本作弹幕强度也不低，这么设计无疑给本来就有一定难度的游戏加大了难度（虽然说是益智动作类游戏，一点躲弹幕基础还是要有的）
2.config是放在游戏外的，虽说个人玩过日版还是明白的，但还要跑到本地文件夹去设置，不得不说有点不人性化。
	[spoiler]3.关于这个翻译。。翻译本身我是不评价，但是同样一句话不论日语还是中文翻译成完整的英语大概都要多占据很多地方。本作中有些地方就没处理好。。直接将字幕挤成一坨放在对话框里，根本看不清（还好这问题并没有在本篇游戏中出现）
   后来问过作者，作者说这是正常设定的表现效果。。。。实话说对玩家来说不怎么友好啊[/spoiler]

另外有时候无法全屏运行游戏，这可能是系统环境问题，个人开全屏时会出现access violation的error窗口。以xp的兼容模式运行后就好了，不知道对各位有没有作用。

最后关于这价格，我只能说见仁见智。	[spoiler]对于我这种即使体会过steam低价，还屁颠屁颠找代购花100+买日本同人游戏的日呆来说，我认为是超值的。（好吧其实当初本来就只是为了ost才买的）[/spoiler]

来还是人参第一次写steam评价，希望能给大家一些参考吧。
